title: Does my ex husband get any of wrongful death settlement?
question: My morher was hit by a company car and now I am suing the company's insurance. This happend when my ex husband and I were legallyseparated. We are currently divorced and I did not list this settlement under an community asset. I have not received any money from the settlement either. I received an email from him stating that he wants a portion of the settlement from my mother. And he also mentioned how wrongful death is considered personal injury which in CA is community asset. Not sure how he found out. I am thinking about getting another lawyer for my mother/dropping lawsuit & then starting the lawsuit all over again with new lawyer. That way there is no way my ex spouse can possible be entitled to any money. Do you think that would be the right choice? Not sure what to do at this point.
answers:
You have standing to assert a claim for the wrongful death of your mother. if your mother was married at the time, her spouse can sue, as can her estate, and any other children she had. it appears she died after you physically separated from your husband. I am not a family lawyer and haven't researched it. If you used community funds related to her death, like paying for her funeral, the community would have a right of reimbursement. Since she apparently died at the scene, I assume there really aren't any medical bills outstanding.

Was your mother providing economic support to you before she passed? if not, you don't have economic losses, nor would the community. I also think since your husband and the community have no legal standing to assert a WD claim here, he and the community have no rights to any settlement you may get for the loss of the relationship you had with your mother. The fact that the accident occurred after you and your husband separated, is also very helpful to your position.

A good family law atty should be able to defeat any claim your soon to be ex may assert. There are other facts that can come into play, so make full disclosure to the atty you are going to see. For example, if your mother had borrowed money from you and your husband while you were together, the community is a creditor of her estate, and could make a claim against the estate. Sometimes there is no estate opened, and no claim brought for the estate. Depending upon her assets, debts, will or trust, it may not be worth the cost to even open an estate and to have it make a claim. Depending upon facts, the estate might end up with some recovery, but the costs and fees eat into it, and then creditors take the rest. You may need to consult with a probate atty as well.
Good luck.

This question should be posted in Family Law.

But DO NOT get rid of your attorney and start this over again.

I do not do family law but this I feel pretty confident that your ex doesn't have a right to anything pertaining to your mother. BUT contact a family law attorney

I disagree that there is a community interest here, although the question would be best answered by a family law specialist. Do not try to hide the claim or the settlement. First, there is no reason to do so; and, second, you would not be "right" in doing so (and for no good reason). I like the advice to tell him to go pound sand.
Your ex has no legal right to any money that your mother/mother's estate would receive as a settlement from this lawsuit. Tell him to go pound sand.

As I read this post - this is your mother's personal injury case and has nothing to do with you or your ex-husband. However, lets assume this is a situation whereat your mother passed as a result of the car accident and you are pursuing a wrongful death action/survivor action. these cross over legal situations are fairly common and attorneys handling wrongful death actions (which are very different than your normal personal injury case) should be able to obtain the answer for you since it can have significant ramifications on your case. I am not your attorney and do not know all the specifics of your case - so I will state a general application of the law - if you were legally separated it is not a community asset. If you were not legally separated it most likely is not a community asset. The Court has the power to make the determination which almost always results in a finding of separate property.

You are not suing fir your personal injuries-- and PI settlements and awards are treated uniquely in California CP law. But it may mater WHAT "append when my ex husband and I were legally separated. ". Was it the accident? or was it the lawsuit? if it was the accident you should have either simply listed it-- or, better yet, gotten expert legal advice.

If you fraudulently concealed this and it is an asset, you could be truly sorry you did.

This is really a wrongful death question with family law overtones. Changing back to wrongful death. You can ask your present attorney if he is entitled to any part of the settlement, and ask for something in writing about his conclusion. Dismissing the lawsuit and filing a new one will not change the ex-husband's rights, if any. Without doing any lengthy research, I believe that any wrongful death settlement would be your separate property, with no rights to your ex. If it was a personal injury lawsuit for you for injuries that happened during the marriage, it might be a different result. Even if you were still married, he is not an heir of your mother, and would have no wrongful death rights to pursue an action.

You can change attorneys at any time. Make sure that your present attorney is not representing you correctly before changing, since that attorney has information that a new attorney would have to develop.
Your attorney should know what to do.

This question should be posted in the family law category, but one thing I can say with some assurance is that I don't follow your theory that changing lawyers will alter the rights of the parties here. You can always change your lawyer if you are not happy with the service you are receiving, but it won't change the facts or the law.

I'd suggest you get a family law expert involved in this matter and make sure that the wrongful death case is pursued with the issues you raise in mind.

If you have a lawyer for the wrongful death suit why don't you ask him about how the proceeds are distributed under California law. You could also consult a family law/divorce attorney. I don't see how changing attorneys or refiling would effect anything but who knows. Let your attorneys that are familiar with your case determine what's the best move for you.
